review_title: Staff are lovely until they get management positions.
pros: The lecturing, admin, cleaning and catering staff are fantastic some of the middle management team are great. I felt like I could speak and engage with anyone in the college. I felt supported by the team I worked with and I had the freedom to teach in my own creative way most of the time.
cons:
1) Senior management don't care about staff or student’s wellbeing. 

2) Senior management don't listen to anybody below them they are very dismissive and do not like to listen to the advice of the staff on the frontline who know more about the day-to-day running of the college than they do.

3) Career progression is poor although there are lots of opportunities for unpaid extra responsibilities and unrecognised workload jobs.

4) Departments are understaffed and oversubscribed, in my last year I had 35hrs per week class contact time and was also teaching more than one class at a time. I wasn't the only one staff are regularly told to carry on enrolling students till they are told to stop by management. Classic line "we will employ more staff if needed" this NEVER happened in my time.

5) Management think it is acceptable to use the HR system as a stick to beat staff with, HR only listen to the side of the management when complaints are made and investigated. 

6) Staff are undervalued to the point of frustration you have a highly experienced and qualified workforce whose opinions don't count. Too many good and experienced staff leave because they are not valued.

7) The college is in the habit of keeping "dead wood" and promoting them beyond what they are capable of.

8) There is far to much paperwork to do, Lecturers are doing too many admin jobs because admin haven't got the personal to cope with it.

9) Students are rushed through courses and given too much "help" with assessments so the college can keep its achievement figures up. 

10) Data is massaged regularly to suit, this is a directive from management to make the college look better than it is, staff feel pressured  to do this to avoid bad departmental reviews which normally would involve extra scrutiny and extra workload.

11) New departments are set up with the focus of getting more students into the college, however due process is not always done and policies and procedures are not put in place early enough in order to safeguard staff and students. 

12) Management are unsupportive of personal issues staff may have and staff are made to feel guilty if they cannot fulfil their duties to the college fully. Management would rather good staff leave than support them through those issues giving them a safe and happy return to work.

13) Workload and expectations are too great for all the reasons mentioned above you are expected to be and outstanding lecturer and deliver outstanding courses all the while dealing with the hidden responsibilities that are expected of you. Staff and Students get a rough deal because of this.

review_title: Poor Hugh Baird College, it never looked like living.
pros: There is a core team of committed and talented front line staff who work hard for students across the college.
cons:
Management are promoted beyond their abilities; as such they are all so far removed from the classroom that they have NO idea how to nurture and develop an educational environment (unless it is found in a dictat from Ofsted). Management is also top heavy and the staffing structure resembles an inverted pyramid - there are more 'Managers', Vice-Principals', 'Assistant-Principals' and 'Directors' than an institution of this size warrants.  Saffing restructures take place every year resulting in front line support and academic staff facing the executioners block. 

Long serving, experienced and Grade 1 staff leave in droves as they are undervalued and pushed beyond reasonable limits, facing constant threats of course closure (without the support of what is mockingly called 'marketing' to properly recruit students). 

EMT goes through whims, making it clear to all other programmes which courses are en vogue - evidenced by the disproportionate and outlandish purchases some programmes benefit from when others struggle to find ESSENTIAL equipment.

HBC resembles a feudal dystopia; with many people vying for a seat at court, but if your face doesn't fit then you are back on the dung-heap.  I've seen it happen first hand to many dedicated and capable lecturers.

pros: I had some lovely and friendly colleagues. We were like one big family! I am still in touch with some of them.  I enjoyed my position very much. Interesting and varied work, everyday. I loved working with students, both the young people, and mature students. I did have a certain amount of flexibility, and was 'my own boss', on a day to day basis.
cons:
Pay could have been more, for the job you did. 
There was very much a negative mindset, with a lot of the staff, which was justified, more often, than not!  It was usually to do with Management, or salaries.  This did impact on many of the staff, which made the actual place quite depressing at times. On the whole, people did not really like working there.
There is no cons at all.
